APEKSHA HOSPITAL, MAHARAGAMA: DONATIONS 615/2025 1. ( () ) (The Hon. (Mrs.) Chamindranee Kiriella, Attorney-at-Law)
asked the Minister of Health and Mass Media:
(a) Will he inform this House of the -
(i) number of patients currently undergoing treatment at the Apeksha Hospital, Maharagama;
(ii) amount of money that had been received by the donation account of the said hospital, as at the beginning of the year 2025;
(iii) amount of money that has been used and has not been used from the account referred to above from the year 2020 to date, separately; and
(iv) measures taken to utilize those monies received as donations by the Apeksha Hospital, Maharagama in a productive manner;

APPOINTMENT OF GRADUATES OF FOREIGN UNIVERSITIES
asked the Minister of Public Administration, Provincial Councils and Local Government:

(i) whether he is aware that the appointments given to graduates of foreign universities as Development Officers during the previous Governments recruitment of Development Officers have subsequently been revoked;
(ii) the specific reasons for such revocation;
(iii) the solution that will be given to the graduates of foreign universities aggrieved by it;
(iv) whether graduates of foreign universities will be recruited to the public sector in future without subjecting them to any injustice or discrimination;
(v) if not, the reasons for it; and

(vi) the solution that will be given to the persons whose appointments to the post of Development Officer were revoked, including those who had not exceeded the age limit of 45 years at the time of recruitment in 2020, but are above that age limit at present?
. ( ) ( . - ) (The Hon. P. Ruwan Senarath - Deputy Minister of Provincial Councils and Local Government) :.

AREAS OF UHANA AND POTTUVIL: ESTABLISHMENT OF
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:
(i) action had been taken to establish separate education zones for the Uhana and Pottuvil areas in the Ampara District, and that the
Governor of the Eastern Province had also given his recommendations for the same; and
(ii) however, the Ministry of Education has not granted its approval for the same?
(i) if so, whether steps will be taken to establish separate education zones for the Uhana and Pottuvil areas; and
(ii) the steps that have been taken in that regard?

(v) whether there is any preparation for putting the tanks to use at present?

Clean Sri Lanka programme 75 '' . . . , . '' . . , ! Clean Sri Lanka programme 75 '' . . '' . . , , 75 '' repair . . , practicality is important. '' , . PHDT . PHDT . PHDT Directors , Regional Plantation Companies CEOs. The CEOs of Regional Plantation Companies are on the Board of Directors of the Plantation Human Development Trust. Here, I want to enlighten everyone on one small matter. You do work through the Plantation Human Development Trust in the Ministry and it is governed and administered by the Regional Plantation Companies. You use taxpayers money to do work in the plantations, regardless of whoever comes to power. However, the people who get credit for it is not the Government, but the companies. If you go on to their websites, you would see posts saying, We have built 44,000 houses. I am sorry to say this, but the companies did not build the houses; it is the successive Governments which had built those houses, using taxpayers money. And, today, those companies take credit for everything that is done inside plantations. They earn profit; they exploit the workers and they have destroyed the "Ceylon Tea" brand. They have done all of that and they are also taking the credit for the work done, which the taxpayers, the Sri Lankan people, are paying for. So, that is something which needs to be looked into because they claim to be ethical, saying they are certified here and certified there. Also, from all those international organizations, they get recognition. Using what? A false pretence, showing that they have done this for their workers, when, in reality, they have not done anything for

the workers! But, everybody is afraid to speak against them. Why? Because they are some of the most powerful lobbyists in the country. And apart from that, nobody wants to hurt the "Ceylon Tea" brand, but, honestly speaking, the "Ceylon Tea" brand does not need to survive on exploitation. That is something that we must come into terms with.

Many people here have a false notion and a false perspective of Jeevan Thodaman, my legacy or our party. I understand that. I am a product of nepotism, I am not saying that I am not. But, at the same time, I do have the backing of not just my community, but also of my voters because I have spoken for them day in, day out in this Parliament; I have stood by them at every given chance. And for that, we have been called opportunists; we have been called many names.

As per what the Hon. Prime Minister said, even in relation to educational reforms, history should not be neglected. Those who do not know history, especially their own history, would cease to exist. We have gone through that for 30 years and I do not think we can go through that again.

Madam, I just want to raise one last matter. As far as all these educational reforms are concerned, you all mentioned earlier that you all had done public consultations prior to coming into power. From what we could see, we do welcome these reforms. However, implementing them is going to be the issue. Of course, you do have our fullest support in their implementation, but, at the same time, there needs to be a complete system change within the plantation sector. If you were to look at what is actually happening there, you would notice that there is only 30 per cent access to quality education in the plantation sector and that it is mainly because we lack teachers. Earlier, we brought in an assistant teacher programme, about which there was some criticism. Why? Because we were taking in students who dropped out of A/Ls, giving them teacher training and posting them as assistant teachers for two years and then, they would become fully-fledged teachers. But, that was criticised. The biggest criticism came from the graduates. But, the truth of the matter is, whether you like it or not, when there is a community which is finding it extremely difficult to have access to quality education, just because of historical injustices, then, they should be given a leeway.

That is equity. We are not asking for equality. When you have one person who is fit and healthy and another who is unable to walk, you cannot tell both of them to climb three flights of steps; that is not possible. To make a long story short, we have started the race 30 years later. We are not asking you to slow down, but just asking to help us out.

The reason I am saying this is because the Government needs to take control of what is inside the plantations. For example, take the 456 estate medical offices, where there are no drugs and doctors; there is

absolutely nothing there. Therefore, the Government needs to take that matter up. There had been a Cabinet Paper passed on that, but, unfortunately, it has not seen implementation. Similarly, in schools, at the end of the day, there needs to be a complete revamp because many teachers do not want to come to the estate schools since it is difficult for them to live there, which is understandable. You cannot force them to teach in a very difficult situation, but there has to be an alternative.

Now, I make a humble request, especially to the Hon. Minister of Women and Child Affairs. Hon. Minister, when I was the Minister, we started a programme along with the ADB, where we were giving free morning meals for about 1,197 crches, child daycare centres. We repaired about 600 of them and there were about 22,000 children. That programme came to a halt. If that could be revived again - that was not done through funding of the Government of Sri Lanka, but through funding of the World Bank and the ADB - it would give more importance to social protection. Secondly, we did a programme with the Indian Government and I am very sure that the Indian Government, too, would be keen on doing that. We had a STEM teacher training programme for science, technology, engineering and maths. We had 19 teachers coming down from Tamil Nadu and they went to all the schools across 13 districts. We created three centres and they trained thousands of teachers and also the children on STEM education. So, that is what is needed.

Lastly, I would also like to inform all of you that vocational training is absolutely necessary - I do agree with that - but, at the same time, vocational training should not become an incentive to drop out from school. That is also a very realistic issue which we are not able to control. Today, the highest number of school dropouts in the estate sector are girls. That is not because of anything, but because of a very simple issue. Their mothers are migrant workers; they go abroad to work leaving their daughters at home with their fathers or with an adult. But, unfortunately, the fathers do not know how to plait the daughters' hair and because of that, they refuse to send them to school. Also, the schools do not have bathrooms. Therefore, it has become very difficult for girls to go to school.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Chairperson of Committees) . ( ) (The Hon. Jeevan Thondaman) I am bringing these matters up because they are more practical problems.

Now, educational reforms are there, which we do welcome. But when it comes to reforms, what I have learnt is, you can put whatever you want on paper, but until and unless there is a visible change, it would actually be very difficult to uplift our community.
Madam, there is just one last thing I would like request from the Government. I think two days ago, there

had been an accident in Uda Radella Estate. Forty three individuals of six families have been affected because a boulder had collapsed and right now, the company is supporting them. If there is anything that the Government could do to intervene and sort that out, we would be grateful for that, too.

I just want a clarification on one last thing. If anybody from the Government could tell me whether you all have decided to give the plantation workers a wage of Rs. 1,700, Rs. 2,000 or Rs. 1,350, I would be grateful.

Gazette could be withdrawn - because there is just a wording issue - and a fresh Gazette could be issued, then that settles the court issue. This information was given to us by the Attorney-General's Department.
Thank you. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Chairperson of Committees) . ]2 .

: .]08] . . Eric J. de Silva "Politics of Education Reform and Other Essays" . Parliament Library : .: : : .: Reforms 44 White Paper . . : : . miss : 44 .:: . The main recommendations in the White Paper were briefly as follows" .20 (e) :

The General Certificate of Education (GCE) will mark the end of the general education span and will serve as the terminal point for the majority of students. The senior secondary (Grades 9-11) curriculum leading to it will consist of the following subjects:
1. First Language 2. Religion 3. Mathematics 4. English 5. Science 6. Social Studies 7. Aesthetic Studies 8. Technical Subjects 9. Health and Physical Education...
Only subjects 1,3,4,5 and 6 First Language, Mathematics, English, Science and Social Studies.
will be tested at the national level by the Department of Examinations while 7 and 8
will be tested at district level; and 9.."
Health and Physical Education will be tested at cluster level.

"...at cluster level. (A decision on the subject of Religion was kept pending until the submission of the report of a committee that had been appointed to examine all aspects of religious education in schools.)
Technical Subject Stream . : . . ]08]: . . :: : .: : . : : ..: . . 27 paragraph .:. I quote:
In the concluding paragraph of its Introduction, the White Paper was to categorically say:

Many an educational reform comes to grief because of hasty implementation without adequate preparation. Not only does this defeat the objectives of the reforms but it invariably causes irreparable damage to the younger generation that becomes the guinea pig of such abortive reforms. Therefore, once the reforms have been accepted after public debate and discussion in legislature all necessary safeguards will be taken to ensure that pupils and students, for whose benefit these reforms are being drawn up do not come by any disabilities as a result of poor planning or implementation
Therefore, Hon. Prime Minister, it is absolutely critical that you get everyone on the same page. : . .:: . 2124 : :: .

Hon. Prime Minister, one other thing we need to understand is that the world is changing. AI is taking over most of the current jobs, but it is also creating new jobs. Even teachers themselves may be replaced by technology.

Hon. Prime Minister, what are the skills a kid starting Grade 1 in 2026 need for him to do a job when he is 22 years old in 2048? To find that out, what I did was, I asked AI what skills would be required. These are the

skills: Adaptability and Continuous Learning; the ability to quickly learn new technologies and adapt to changing roles will be paramount; Technology Proficiency; Complex Problem Solving; Communications and Collaboration; Leadership and Social Influence; Creativity and Innovation and Emotional Intelligence. So, those are the skills that they need to have as adults going out to face the global competitive economy. So, the curricula need to change.

. ; . , , personality, graduate . Finland, Canada, Singapore, Israel, Rwanda, South Korea, Tanzania - bilingual - , . . , . Because of that, they have benefitted a lot in areas such as educational excellence, inclusive society, unity, bilingual workforce, better public service access, economic growth, social harmony, global competency, cultural identity, national unity, global

integration and innovation. So, those people and countries have improved further in those areas. Likewise, recently in Malaysia also, they have developed their system according to their language policy. But, in Sri Lanka, we, the Sinhalese, the Muslims and the Tamils, are unable to communicate even among ourselves due to not knowing the languages. Sinhalese people cannot speak Tamil and Tamil people cannot speak Sinhala and we are also very poor in communicating in the link language. We have to develop the system of using languages in issuing circulars. Still, when issuing letters also, the police use their mother tongue and they are unable to use the second language or the link language as well. Because of that, people suffer a lot.

[3.38 p.m.] () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Ramanathan Archchuna) Hon. Presiding Member, I would like to start my speech with the following words of former President J.R. Jayewardene in 1983: I am not worried about the opinion of the Jaffna people. Now, we cannot think of them, not about their lives or their opinion. The more you put pressure in the North, the happier the Sinhala people will be in the South. Really, if I starve the Tamils out, the Sinhala people will be happy. In 1983, President J.R. Jayewardene said those words.

Yesterday was the remembrance day of the Black July of 1983. Unfortunately, when I speak in Parliament, even though I speak in Tamil, the Hon. Prime Minister is not willing to listen; she never uses the headset to listen to the interpretation of my speeches. That is how the Tamil people are ignored in the august Chamber. Sir, I would like to speak further in Tamil.

. . 51 . . : : : : .I must bring to your notice that there is a programme called Climate-Resilient Infrastructure Project. At least through that, some funds should have been allocated for renovation of those buildings that have been affected by climate-related issues. Therefore, I would like to bring those issues to your concern.

I must congratulate the Prime Minister for all this work. But, there are issues concerning higher education, regarding which you and I were in the same Select Committee. Of course, you had a dissenting report basically going by ideological issues. You have differences with our views regarding higher education, but we would like to urge you to reconsider some of your concepts in keeping with the current trends in higher education. Particularly, I would like to bring to your notice an article that had been published by Prof. Mohan De Silva, former Chairman of the UGC, titled "Present and future trends in global student mobility seeking medical education and training: opportunities and threats for Sri Lanka" and he has pointed out that among the students seeking education in British universities, Sri Lanka has become only second to China. China has a more than 1.2 billion population, but from among the

students going to UK, Sri Lanka is in the second place compared to China, India and various other massive populous countries. So, that is happening. Recently, we saw an unfortunate incident in the Faculty of Medicine at the Kotelawala Defence University, where you had taken a sudden decision not to recruit local students. You have now reversed it, but I must say that particularly when it comes to medical education, it is a fact that communist countries like Vietnam, China and many other countries allowed private medical schools to come up. I think we have to change and move away from the current concept and accommodate private medical schools in order to make Sri Lanka a preferred destination for higher education and also to prevent our foreign exchange from going out of the country.

And it being past 5.30 p.m., THE HON. PRESIDING MEMBER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 6.02 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Friday, 25th July, 2025.
